org.jcvi.jillion.internal.core.util

Class GrowableShortArray

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jcvi.jillion.internal.core.util.GrowableShortArray
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Iterable<Short>

    public final class GrowableShortArray
extends Object
implements Iterable<Short>
    A GrowableShortArray is a utility class that wraps a short array that will dynamically grow as needed when data is appended, inserted, replaced and removed etc. This is similar to an ArrayList or StringBuilder for primitive shorts. This class is not Thread-safe.
    Author:
    dkatzel

    • Constructor Detail

      • GrowableShortArray

        public GrowableShortArray(int initialCapacity)
        Creates a new GrowableShortArray with the given initial capacity.
        Parameters:
        initialCapacity - the initial size of the backing short array. When adding shorts will cause the short array to overflow, the backing short array will automatically grow larger.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if initialCapacity is <=0.

      • GrowableShortArray

        public GrowableShortArray(Collection<Short> shorts)
        Creates a new GrowableShortArray where the backing array contains the contents of the given Collection stored as primitives. The order in the array is the determined by the Collection's iteration order. The capacity and length of this growable array are set to the collection's size.
        Parameters:
        shorts - the Collection of Integers to create into a growable array from.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if the given collection is null or any elements in the collection are null.

      • GrowableShortArray

        public GrowableShortArray(short[] shorts)
        Creates a new GrowableShortArray where the backing short array is an exact copy of the input array and the initial capacity is set to the array length. This has similar (although optimized) functionality to 
         short[] shorts = ...
 GrowableShortArray gba = new GrowableShortArray(shorts.length);
 gba.append(shorts);
        Parameters:
        shorts - the initial short values to set to the backing array.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if shorts is null.

        public GrowableShortArray copy()
        Create a new instance of GrowableShortArray that is an exact copy of this instance. Any future modifications to either the original instance or the copy will NOT be reflected in the other.
        Returns:
        a new instance of GrowableShortArray that contains the same data as this instance currently does.

        public short remove(int offset)
        Removes the value at the given offset and shifts all downstream elements down by 1.
        Parameters:

        Returns:
        the short value removed.

      • getCurrentCapacity

        public int getCurrentCapacity()
        Get the current capacity of the backing array. This may be larger than the value returned by getCurrentLength(). Modifying this growable array to extend beyond the current capacity will require the backing array to be grown.
        Returns:
        the current capacity; will always be >=0;

      • toArray

        public short[] toArray()

      • binarySearch

        public int binarySearch(short key)
        Searches the current values in this growable array using the binary search algorithm as implemented by Arrays.binarySearch(short[], short). The array must be sorted (as by the sort() method) prior to making this call. If it is not sorted, the results are undefined. If the array contains multiple elements with the specified value, there is no guarantee which one will be found.
        Parameters:
        key - the value to be searched for.
        Returns:
        index of the search key, if it is contained in the array; otherwise, (-(insertion point) - 1). The insertion point is defined as the point at which the key would be inserted into the array: the index of the first element greater than the key, or a.length if all elements in the array are less than the specified key. Note that this guarantees that the return value will be >= 0 if and only if the key is found.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if fromIndex > toIndex
        ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - if fromIndex < 0 or toIndex > a.length
        See Also:
        Arrays.binarySearch(byte[], byte)

      • sortedRemove

        public boolean sortedRemove(short value)
        Remove the given value from this sorted array. This method assumes that the values in the backing array have been previously sorted. If this sorted array contains several indexes with this value then only one will be removed and it is undefined which one will actually be removed. Calling this method on an unsorted backing array may not remove the value correctly.
        Parameters:
        value - the value to remove
        Returns:
        true if the value was found and removed; false if the value does not exist in the sorted backing array.

      • sortedInsert

        public int sortedInsert(short value)
        Insert the given value into the sorted backing array. Calling this method on an unsorted backing array may not insert the value correctly.
        Parameters:
        value - the value to insert.
        Returns:
        the index that this value was inserted into.

      • sort

        public void sort()
        Sort the current values in this growable array using the default comparator.

      • clear

        public void clear()
        Set the current length to 0.

      • iterator

        public Iterator<Short> iterator()
        Specified by:
        iterator in interface Iterable<Short>

      • sortedInsert

        public void sortedInsert(short[] values)
        Insert the given sorted array of values into the sorted backing array. This should produce identical results to iterating over the array and calling sortedInsert(short) on each element, but is hopefully more efficient. Calling this method on an unsorted backing array may not insert the value correctly.
        Parameters:
        values - the values to insert.

      • getCount

        public int getCount(short value)
        Get the number of values in this array that currently have the given value.
        Parameters:
        value - the value to look for.
        Returns:
        the number of cells with the value; will always be >= 0.
